verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses on Mount Sinai, saying,
verses.comment: The setting is clarified—God gives this law while Moses is on Sinai, highlighting the authoritative source of the law. This connects to the giving of the covenant (Exodus 19).

verses.text: "Speak to the people of Israel and say to them: When you come into the land that I am giving you, the land shall keep a Sabbath to the LORD.
verses.comment: The Sabbath rest here expands from a weekly day to the land itself every seven years. This foreshadows the idea of rest and restoration (Hebrews 4:9-10).

verses.text: For six years you shall sow your field, and for six years you shall prune your vineyard and gather in its fruits,
verses.comment: A parallel to the six days of labor before the Sabbath day, teaching both stewardship and trust in God’s providence.

verses.text: but in the seventh year there shall be a Sabbath of horses rest for the land, a Sabbath to the LORD. You shall not sow your field or prune your vineyard.
verses.comment: The land’s rest is a reminder of the Lord’s authority over creation and connects Sabbath theology with stewardship.

verses.text: What grows by itself in your harvest you shall not reap, and the grapes of your untended vine you shall not gather; it shall be a year of solemn rest for the land.
verses.comment: Even voluntary growth cannot be harvested—rest and trust override normal economic activity. The discipline fosters reliance upon God, as later emphasized in New Testament teachings (Matt. 6:25-34).

verses.text: The Sabbath of the land shall provide food for you—for yourself, for your male and female slaves, for your hired servant and for the foreigner who sojourns with you;
verses.comment: The produce is meant as provision for all within the community, reflecting God's concern for justice and charity—important themes throughout Scripture.

verses.text: and for your cattle and for the wild animals that are in your land; all its produce shall be for food.
verses.comment: The Sabbath provision extends even to animals, showing God's mercy and the interconnectedness of all creation (cf. Psalm 104).

verses.text: "You shall count seven Sabbaths of years—seven times seven years—so that the time of the seven Sabbaths of years gives you forty-nine years.
verses.comment: The emphasis on 'seven sevens'—49 years—links to completion and fullness, concepts deep in biblical numerology and prophecy.

verses.text: Then you shall sound the loud trumpet on the tenth day of the seventh month. On the Day of Atonement you shall sound the trumpet throughout all your land.
verses.comment: Jubilee begins at the Day of Atonement—a profound union of forgiveness, release, and freedom, prefiguring the redemptive work of Christ (Luke 4:18-19).

verses.text: And you shall consecrate the fiftieth year, and proclaim liberty throughout the land to all its inhabitants. It shall be a jubilee for you; each of you shall return to his own property and each of you shall return to his own family.
verses.comment: Jubilee: release and restoration. This prefigures Christ’s declaration of the 'year of the Lord’s favor'—a theme picked up by Luke’s Gospel (Luke 4:18).

verses.text: That fiftieth year shall be a jubilee for you; in it you shall neither sow nor reap what grows of itself nor gather the grapes from your untended vines.
verses.comment: Another year of special rest, underscoring trust in God's ongoing provision and the rhythm of sacred time.

verses.text: For it is a jubilee; it shall be holy to you. You shall eat its increase out of the field.
verses.comment: Holiness and jubilee are linked—God’s desire is a consecrated people who participate in rhythms of grace and liberation.

verses.text: "In this year of jubilee each of you shall return to his own property.
verses.comment: Restoration of property—symbolizing equality and reversal of fortune, a foreshadowing of divine justice and ultimate restoration in Christ.

verses.text: And if you make a sale to your neighbor or buy from your neighbor, you shall not wrong one another.
verses.comment: Reinforces justice in transactions—anticipates Christ’s command to love one’s neighbor as oneself (Mark 12:31).

verses.text: You shall pay your neighbor according to the number of years after the jubilee, and he shall sell to you according to the number of years of crops.
verses.comment: Land transactions are not permanent, they are leases based on proximity to jubilee—emphasizing God’s ultimate ownership.

verses.text: If the years are many, you shall increase the price, and if the years are few, you shall reduce the price, for it is the number of crops that he is selling to you.
verses.comment: The regulation reflects fairness and stewardship, which remain important for the Church and Christian conscience.

verses.text: You shall not oppress one another, but you shall fear your God, for I am the LORD your God.
verses.comment: The fear of God governs economic and social life. Reverence for God motivates justice toward others.

verses.text: "Therefore you shall perform my statutes and keep my rules and do them, and you will dwell in the land securely.
verses.comment: Obedience leads to blessing and security—a recurring theme throughout Scripture (Deut. 28).

verses.text: The land will yield its fruit, and you will eat your fill and dwell there in safety.
verses.comment: Material blessings follow covenant faithfulness—earthly abundance as a sign of God’s favor, yet calling the soul to gratitude and spiritual dependence.

verses.text: If you say, 'What shall we eat in the seventh year, if we may not sow or gather our harvest?'
verses.comment: The question anticipates human anxiety about provision, similar to Israel’s wilderness doubt (Exodus 16).

verses.text: I will command my blessing on you in the sixth year, so that it will produce fruit for three years.
verses.comment: God assures abundant provision—pointing ahead to Christ’s multiplication of bread (John 6), who himself is the provision and bread of life.

verses.text: When you sow in the eighth year, you will still be eating from the old harvest; until the ninth year, when its produce comes in, you will eat the old.
verses.comment: God’s abundance suffices for all who obey—mirroring trust in divine timing, as when Christ instructs not to worry about tomorrow (Matt. 6:34).

verses.text: "The land shall not be sold permanently, for the land is mine; for you are strangers and sojourners with me.
verses.comment: God’s declared ownership is foundational; stewardship is key. Believers today are also 'pilgrims' in this world (Hebrews 11:13).

verses.text: And in all the recurring land of your possession, you shall grant a redemption for the land.
verses.comment: ‘Redemption’ of land foreshadows Christ the Redeemer, whose work purchases freedom for the world (Eph. 1:7).

verses.text: "If your brother becomes poor and sells some of his property, then his nearest relative shall come and redeem what his brother has sold.
verses.comment: 'Kinsman redeemer'—a type of Christ, who redeems the lost spiritual inheritance on behalf of his brothers (Hebrews 2:11-15).

verses.text: If a man has no one to redeem it, but he himself becomes able to redeem it,
verses.comment: Redemption is possible if means are provided. This principle foreshadows the hope of restored relationship God promises all in Christ (Rom. 5:10).

verses.text: then let him calculate the years since its sale and refund the balance to the man to whom he sold it, and return to his property.
verses.comment: Justice and equity in all dealings, reflecting God’s own character.

verses.text: But if he cannot redeem it for himself, then what he has sold shall remain in the hand of the buyer until the year of jubilee. In the jubilee it shall be released, and he shall return to his property.
verses.comment: Jubilee ensures ultimate restoration, as God's grace overturns misfortune and slavery—a vision fulfilled in Christ (John 8:36).

verses.text: If anyone sells a dwelling house in a walled city, he may redeem it within a year after its sale; for a full year he shall have the right of redemption.
verses.comment: Urban property follows a stricter rule—reflecting social order. The one-year right protects families, but balances public and private interests.

verses.text: If it is not redeemed within a full year, then the house in the walled city shall belong permanently to the buyer throughout his generations; it shall not be released in the jubilee.
verses.comment: A difference is made between rural and urban properties; perpetual family inheritance is prioritized for agricultural land—connecting to promises in the patriarchal era.

verses.text: However, the houses of villages which have no wall around them shall be counted as open country. They can be redeemed, and they shall be released in the jubilee.
verses.comment: Houses in open country follow the rural land laws—God’s law protects the agrarian structure and family welfare.

verses.text: As for the cities of the Levites, the Levites may redeem at any time the houses in the cities they possess.
verses.comment: Special status for Levites—God’s provision for those consecrated to his service, a theme which echoes throughout Israel’s worship and leadership structures.

verses.text: If one of the Levites exercises his right of redemption, then the house that was sold in a city belonging to him shall be released in the jubilee; for the houses in the cities of the Levites are their property among the Israelites.
verses.comment: Levites’ inheritance is spiritual, distributed among Israel. Their redemption points to the enduring place of service in God’s plan—hinting at the importance of a dedicated ministry in the New Testament (Acts 13:2).

verses.text: But the fields of pastureland belonging to their cities may not be sold, for that is their perpetual possession.
verses.comment: Provision for the ministers of God remains secure; their service to the people is foundational, and their needs are provided by the community (Numbers 18:20-24).

verses.text: "If your brother becomes poor and cannot maintain himself with you, you shall support him as though he were a stranger and a sojourner, and he shall live with you.
verses.comment: Charity and hospitality are hallmarks of the law; this prefigures the New Testament command to assist the poor (Matt. 25:35-40).

verses.text: Take no interest or profit from him, but fear your God, so that your brother may live beside you.
verses.comment: Usury is forbidden within the community of faith, expressing mercy and solidarity; a principle often invoked in Christian ethical teaching.

verses.text: You shall not lend him your money at interest, nor give him your food for profit.
verses.comment: Evokes a moral economy—serving one another and not seeking gain at the expense of the vulnerable, echoing Christ’s concern for the poor.

verses.text: I am the LORD your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt to give you the land of Canaan, and to be your God.
verses.comment: God’s redemptive acts are foundation for the law; Christians recognize this in God’s saving work in Christ and the new Exodus he brings (Luke 9:31).

verses.text: "If your brother becomes poor beside you and sells himself to you, you shall not make him serve as a slave.
verses.comment: Enslavement within God’s people is prohibited—dignity is restored, pointing to how Christian community upholds freedom in Christ.

verses.text: He shall be with you as a hired servant and as a temporary resident; he shall serve with you until the year of jubilee.
verses.comment: Limits on servitude—God’s design is freedom and restoration, culminating in the jubilee, a symbol of complete redemption.

verses.text: Then he and his children with him shall go free, and return to his own family and to the property of his fathers.
verses.comment: Freedom for the family—God’s justice restores relationships and possessions; this restoration is fulfilled spiritually in salvation (Gal. 4:7).

verses.text: For they are my servants whom I brought out of the land of Egypt; they shall not be sold as slaves.
verses.comment: God’s redemption creates a new identity; spiritual freedom is secured for his people—a principle clarified in the Gospel (John 8:35-36).

verses.text: You shall not rule over him ruthlessly, but shall fear your God.
verses.comment: Exploitation is condemned, with God’s fear and justice as the standard for all relationships in the community.

verses.text: As for your male and female slaves whom you may have from the nations around you, from them you may buy male and female slaves.
verses.comment: There is a distinction between Israelite and foreign slaves. The fuller revelation in Christ points toward universal dignity and calls all cultures to higher mercy (Gal. 3:28).

verses.text: You may also buy from among the strangers who dwell with you, and from their families who are with you, whom they have fathered in your land, and they shall be your property.
verses.comment: This reflects the social reality of the time, but Scripture plants seeds that will blossom into a fuller revelation of human dignity (Philemon 1:16).

verses.text: You may bequeath them to your sons after you, to inherit as a possession forever. You may make them serve you, but over your brothers, the Israelites, you shall not rule, one over another, with ruthlessness.
verses.comment: Even in the Old Testament, God’s people are to exercise restraint and compassion; later teaching of Christ perfects this ethic (John 13:34-35).

verses.text: "If a stranger or sojourner with you becomes rich, and your brother beside him becomes poor and sells himself to the stranger or sojourner with you or to a member of the stranger’s family,
verses.comment: It is possible for Israelites to become servants of foreigners as economic cycles turn, but God’s justice works for restoration.

verses.text: after he is sold he may be redeemed. One of his brothers may redeem him,
verses.comment: The kinsman redeemer theme appears again—salvation and restoration are communal, prefiguring Christ’s redemptive mission for his brethren (Hebrews 2:11).

verses.text: or his uncle or his cousin may redeem him, or any of his close relatives may redeem him. Or if he becomes rich, he may redeem himself.
verses.comment: Multiple avenues for redemption echo the importance of family, community, and personal responsibility; spiritually, redemption is always open in Christ.

verses.text: He shall calculate with his buyer from the year when he sold himself to him until the year of jubilee. The price of his release shall be calculated according to the number of years. It shall be as the time of a hired servant with him.
verses.comment: Equity is maintained—God’s law is just and merciful, preventing perpetual servitude, just as Christ’s deliverance is complete.

verses.text: If there are still many years, according to them he shall refund from his redemption price the amount for his release.
verses.comment: Righteous calculation ensures that redemption is fair and achievable, an image of Christ’s payment, which is sufficient for all.

verses.text: If there remain but a few years until the year of jubilee, he shall calculate with him; according to the years he shall refund the amount for his release.
verses.comment: The cost of redemption decreases as the jubilee approaches—pointing to the ultimate liberation at God’s appointed time.

verses.text: He shall be with him as a servant hired year by year. He shall not rule over him ruthlessly in your sight.
verses.comment: Justice and mercy together—slavery is regulated so that it does not become oppression, and the community is responsible for its oversight.

verses.text: And if he is not redeemed in any of these ways, then he and his children with him shall go free in the year of jubilee.
verses.comment: Jubilee’s final release is assured—God’s ultimate intention is freedom for his people. Spiritually, Christ is our jubilee from sin and death.

verses.text: For to me the children of Israel are servants; they are my servants, whom I brought out of the land of Egypt. I am the LORD your God."
verses.comment: God’s claim over his people is as Redeemer and Lord. The New Testament affirms this identity in Christ—“bought with a price” (1 Cor. 6:20).
